Award.AwardTitle: UC Denver Women in Engineering, Science and Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The UC - Denver IT Catalyst project will acquire and analyze baseline faculty data as a mechanism for preparing the institution for transformation to comprehensively support women faculty in the STEM disciplines. Because women are underrepresented among STEM faculty, especially at the rank of Full Professor, this project will conduct both quantitative and qualitative assessments of the status of women in science at UCD, focusing on the STEM disciplines but also including the social and behavioral sciences. Specifically, this project will address three specific aims: 1) Acquire and analyze qualitative and quantitative baseline data regarding the current status of women faculty in STEM+ departments at UC Denver, 2) Gather information about best practices, lessons learned, pitfalls, and progress from ADVANCE-IT recipient institutions and other established and successful programs supporting women in STEM+ disciplines, and 3) Use the information gathered in Specific Aims 1 and 2 to develop a cooperative plan with the campus administration for institutional transformation that supports women faculty in STEM disciplines throughout their careers at UC Denver.

Intellectual Merit: The UC Denver IT Catalyst project will shed light on the degree to which University policies and work/life issues affect professional outcomes for women faculty using an emperically-based foundation.

Broader Impacts: This project has potential to positively impact retention and advancement at other Colorado colleges and Universities and other campuses in the CUSystem, particularly the medical school with which this regional campus as most recently become associated. An important component of the project includes dissemination of findings and plans to the larger academic and scientific community through national meetings and conferences. Also, it is anticipated that an institutional transformation plan will be beneficial for all UCD faculty, students and staff and can be a model for other similar institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ADVANCE is an NSF-funded grant program with the goal of developing systemic approaches to increase the representation and advancement of women in academic STEM careers, thereby contributing to the development of a more diverse science and engineering workforce.  ADVANCE also has as its goal to seminally contribute to and inform the general knowledge base on gender equity in the academic STEM disciplines.

The University of Colorado Denver (CU Denver), a comprehensive campus in a diverse urban community, was awarded funding for its first ADVANCE project in the Fall of 2010. This ADVANCE IT-Catalyst funding opportunity is designed to support institutions in their efforts to conduct institutional self-assessment activities (data collection, data analysis, policy review) in order to identify specific issues in the recruitment, retention and promotion of women faculty in STEM disciplines. This area of work is considered fundamental for all institutions of higher education that plan to undertake institutional transformation.

Throughout the course of the ADVANCE-IT Catalyst grant at CU Denver, the focus has been to identify any systematic gender differences in and relationships between appointments, rank, pay and productivity and to determine factors that directly relate to faculty satisfaction at various ranks and disciplines, particularly for women.  Funding for this project has provided resources to gather data from STEM, STEM-plus (other integrated science fields supported by NSF) and non-STEM fields from ADVANCE generated climate surveys, analyses of institutional research data, annual productivity reports, interviews and feedback from institutional discussions.

To this end, quantitative and qualitative data have been collected to gain an understanding of the University’s strengths and challenges in fostering career growth among women faculty. Funding from the NSF has contributed to the collection of data from a campus-wide climate survey and interviews with faculty.  Funding from NSF combined with institutional resources dedicated to the project goals, afforded the opportunity for the collection of information on hiring, retention, tenure, promotion and compensation of faculty beyond the STEM disciplines to allow comparisons of STEM with non-STEM, women with men, and tenure-track and non-tenure-track faculty as a valuable outgrowth of this project. 

The collection and econometric analyses of these data have provided important information about successes, institutional challenges and opportunities for growth at the university to promote career growth among female STEM faculty in particular with expected benefits to all faculty throughout the university.   This project provided the impetus for wide-ranging discussions about important institutional approaches that could improve retention and advancement of women in STEM fields and opportunities for mentoring and information for women STEM faculty. Improving retention and advancement is valuable for the cultivation of a diverse workforce in the STEM fields and individual growth and success, but also enhances the university’s ability to maintain and improve its productivity in a cost-effective manner.  Recruiting and replacing faculty and administrators with external candidates is far more costly than growing and retaining the best from within.

Detailed analyses from these data yield many findings that are consistent with the experiences of other universities but some that are unique to our institution. Our research indicates that gender-based pay differences are largely due to differences in the gender distribution and salary differentials across faculty ranks. As is the case at most universities, females are more likely to be in non-tenure-track positions and are less likely to have achieved the rank of full professor. Based on data obtained from surveys and interviews funded as part of this project, uncertainty about the promotion process and perceived benefits likely contributes to the underrepresentation of women at higher ranks. The results of our analyses add to the understanding of the barriers often faced by women in STEM fields.  The development, adoption and evaluation of strategies to overcome these barriers will be disseminated to other programs and institutions.  

As a culmination of the project, the team worked administrators, faculty and professional organizations to develop informational programs and mentoring strategies as part of an application for an ADVANCE PAID grant from the National Science Foundation.  The results of this project will also serve to inform administrators and faculty who assume leadership positions to continue to explore avenues to promote female faculty and student success.  Visible female role models in STEM research, education, administration and leadership positions are vital to promote STEM careers among female students.
